sub_topic: Finding the derivative of a function
message_1: Find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 7x^3 + 4x^2 + 9x - 2 at x=2.
message_2:
To find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 7x^3 + 4x^2 + 9x - 2, we will first find the derivative of each term with respect to x, and then evaluate the derivative at x = 2.

The derivative of f(x) with respect to x is:

f'(x) = d(3x^4)/dx - d(7x^3)/dx + d(4x^2)/dx + d(9x)/dx - d(2)/dx

Using the power rule for derivatives (d(x^n)/dx = nx^(n-1)), we get:

f'(x) = 12x^3 - 21x^2 + 8x + 9

Now, we will evaluate the derivative at x = 2:

f'(2) = 12(2)^3 - 21(2)^2 + 8(2) + 9
f'(2) = 12(8) - 21(4) + 16 + 9
f'(2) = 96 - 84 + 16 + 9
f'(2) = 12 + 16 + 9
f'(2) = 37

So, the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 7x^3 + 4x^2 + 9x - 2 at x = 2 is 37.
